meanings.definition: To be less active or intense
meanings.sent1: After playing for hours, he slacked off and took a break.
meanings.sent2: She slacked in her studies and her grades dropped.
meanings.sent3: The cat slacked in chasing the mouse, pretending to be tired.
meanings.sent4: The wind slacked its howling as the storm passed.
meanings.sent5: The runner slacked his pace as he approached the finish line.

meanings.definition: To fail to keep up with a standard or deadline
meanings.sent1: He slacked on submitting his assignment on time.
meanings.sent2: The team slacked in meeting the project deadline.
meanings.sent3: The baker slacked on baking the cake, causing a delay.
meanings.sent4: The student's attention slacked as the clock ticked closer to the deadline.
meanings.sent5: The employee slacked off and missed the important deadline.

meanings.definition: To loosen or make less tight
meanings.sent1: She slacked the rope to make it easier to climb.
meanings.sent2: The tailor slacked the belt to make it more comfortable.
meanings.sent3: The grip on the jar slacked, making it easier to open.
meanings.sent4: The tension in the room slacked as the meeting ended.
meanings.sent5: He slacked the reins to give the horse more freedom.
